Reifler suggests it[.] because conservatives are more rigid than liberals. Maybe so. If I had to guess, though, I'd say it[.] because right-wing talkers have spent so many years deriding "so-called experts" that they now have negative credibility with many conservatives. 

From a cursory reading of the article, it[.] an American study. It doesn't mean the findings are relevant in other countries and political environments. If a left-wing talkers spend a lot of time deriding "so-called experts", then the_left_wing base would be just as rigid. For instance, the Canadian left[.] backfire effect to anything the Fraser-Institute, Jack Mintz, or Tom Flanagan is probably just as strong.

 We showed that the natural sciences and business disciplines are more right-leaning, while social_sciences, humanities, arts, and education are more left-leaning in terms of party affiliation and political orientation. It is perhaps not surprising that the role of social critic is more likely found in the social_sciences, humanities, education, and arts and less so in business, engineering, and natural sciences.

Your description of a liberal population can also describe a university graduate. Universities churn out more graduates in liberal leaning faculties than right_leaning facilities, such as STEM majors and business. I wonder if your verified, statistical truths account for this. You can attribute being knowledgeable about intellectually engaging topics to political affiliations, I'm going to attribute it to being university educated.
